tn.text: Parallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_poetry]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
This psalm is a song about God's faithfulness.
"This is for the director of music to use in worship"
One of David's chief musicians had this same name. This may refer to him. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:psa:039:001|39:1]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
Possible meanings are 1) David wrote the psalm or 2) the psalm is about David or 3) the psalm is in the style of David's psalms.
"he is the one who rescues me" or "he is the one who saves me"

tn.ref: He alone is my rock and my salvation
tn.text: The writer speaks of God's ability to protect him as if God were a rock. AT: "He is the only one who can protect and rescue me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
The writer speaks of God's ability to protect him as if God were a high tower. AT: "he keeps me away from the grasp of my enemies" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: I will not be greatly moved
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "nothing can ever move me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"my enemies" or "all my enemies"

tn.ref: How long ... will you attack a man ... or a shaky fence?
tn.text: David uses a rhetorical question to express his frustration. No answer is expected. AT: "It seems like my enemies will never stop attacking me. I feel that I am as weak against you as a leaning wall or a broken-down fence." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
"attack me"

tn.ref: They consult with him only to
tn.text: "They intend to" or "They plan to"

tn.ref: consult with him ... bring him ... bless him ... curse him
tn.text: In these verses, David is referring to himself by "him."
This refers to their speech or their words. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This refers to their thoughts. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: for my hopes are set on him
tn.text: "for I place my hope in him"

tn.ref: He alone is my rock and my salvation; he is my high tower
tn.text: The writer speaks of God as if he were a rock and a high tower. Both of these metaphors show how God provides protection from one's enemies. Here "salvation" means that God rescues the writer. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:psa:062:001|62:2]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
This can be stated in active form. AT: "nothing can move me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: the rock of my strength and my refuge are in God
tn.text: The writer speaks of God as if he were a rock that keeps one safe from his enemies. He also speaks of God as if he were a shelter that provides protection. AT: "God always gives me strength and protection" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
This refers to telling God your inner feelings as if you were pouring out a liquid. AT: "give your deepest concerns to God" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
The word "us" refers to David and the people he is speaking to. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_inclusive]])

tn.ref: men of low standing ... men of high standing are a lie
tn.text: This refers to men of all levels of wealth and importance. The phrases "are vanity" and "are a lie" have the same meaning. One cannot confidently trust in anyone.  AT: "you cannot place your trust in men, no matter how important they are" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_merism]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: weighed together, they are lighter than nothing
tn.text: If you put all of these kinds of men together on a scale, they would have no weight. This means that they have no real value to you.
These two words have basically the same meaning. You cannot trust in money that you get by taking it from other people. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])

tn.ref: for they will bear no fruit
tn.text: The writer speaks of riches as if they were trees or vines that could bear fruit. AT: "for they will provide nothing good for you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: do not fix your heart on them
tn.text: Here "fix your heart" is an idiom that means to desire something greatly. AT: "do not desire them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: God has spoken once, twice have I heard this
tn.text: This means that God has said this more than once.
"God is the one who really has power"

tn.ref: Also to you, Lord, belongs covenant faithfulness
tn.text: "he is the one who faithfully loves us, as he promised" (UDB)

tn.ref: for you pay back every person for what he has done
tn.text: The writer speaks of God's rewards as if he were paying a wage for work. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
